Title: Border Force officer
Overview: Border Force officers protect UK border entry points like ports and airports, by enforcing immigration and customs regulations.

EntryRouteSummary: You can get into this job through:an apprenticeship; working your way up; applying directly; a graduate training scheme

RelevantSubjects: You could do a public service operational delivery advanced apprenticeship with the Civil Service.
Apprenticeship.EntryRequirementPreface: To do this apprenticeship, you'll need:
EntryRequirements: 2 or more GCSEs at grades 9 to 4 (A* to C), or equivalent, including English and maths

Work: You could join the Civil Service as a Border Force assistant officer, then apply for an officer post when vacancies become available.
To do this, you'll usually need 5 GCSEs at grades 9 to 4 (A* to C), including English and maths, or equivalent qualifications.
DirectApplication: You could apply directly to become a Border Force officer. To enter at officer level, you may need at least 2 A levels at grade E or above, or equivalent qualifications.
OtherRoutes: You can apply through the [Civil Service Fast Stream | https://www.faststream.gov.uk/] if you have a degree.

FurtherInformation: You can find out more about working as a Border Force officer from [Border Force | https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/border-force/about/recruitment] and [Civil Service Careers | https://www.civil-service-careers.gov.uk/].

WhatItTakes.DigitalSkillsLevel: to be able to carry out basic tasks on a computer or hand-held device

Skills.Description: excellent verbal communication skills
patience and the ability to remain calm in stressful situations
the ability to think clearly using logic and reasoning
the ability to work well with others
knowledge of English language
customer service skills
to be thorough and pay attention to detail
the ability to accept criticism and work well under pressure
to be flexible and open to change
thinking and reasoning skills
legal knowledge including court procedures and government regulations
knowledge of public safety and security
active listening skills
the ability to read English
knowledge of psychology
excellent written communication skills
the ability to monitor your own performance and that of your colleagues
concentration skills
the ability to work well with your hands
physical skills like movement, coordination, dexterity and grace

RelatedRestrictions: have lived in the UK for the last 5 years
have a good level of fitness

WYDDayToDayTasks: In this role you could be:checking travel documents and passports; questioning passengers about their reasons for visiting the UK; searching people, luggage and vehicles; writing case notes; working with the police and immigration officials on operations; attending court as a witness

WorkingEnvironment.Location: You could work at a border post.
WorkingEnvironment.Environment: Your working environment may be physically demanding and outdoors in all weathers.
WorkingEnvironment.Uniform: You may need to wear a uniform.

CareerPathAndProgression: You'll get continuous training during your first 6 to 12 months. Once you've passed your probationary period, you'll have the full responsibilities of a Border Force officer.
With experience you could become a team leader, or move into a management position. You could also use your skills to train and work with new staff.

You may also be able to apply for roles in other departments of the [Home Office | https://www.civil-service-careers.gov.uk/departments/working-for-the-home-office/] or [Civil Service | https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/civil-service/about/recruitment].
